awd_abstract_narration:
The project, building on very recent experimental and computational methodologies, investigates at atomic level detail the key macromolecular apparatus that generates energy from sun light or food in higher life forms.  Outcomes of the research are new solutions for solar energy conversion and agriculture as well as health benefits. The research extends the size scale of macromolecular systems within cells that can be studied and advances the technological frontier of computational technologies employed in the life sciences. The project provides an exceptional interdisciplinary training opportunity for young researchers from the fields of biology, chemistry, physics, and computer science. Planned activities also include development of advanced visualization and analysis tools, dissemination of teaching material on photosynthesis and respiration, and the production of a movie "Birth of Planet Earth" showcasing the early evolution of photosynthesis establishing life on Earth.

Two ubiquitous biological energy conversion systems are investigated: the thylakoid systems of plant chloroplasts and the respiratory complex of mitochondria. The two macromolecular systems involve large protein complexes and share physical processes as well as constituent proteins. The project combines molecular electronics, stochastic quantum mechanics, and molecular dynamics methods to answer critical questions in bioenergetics: how do the many participating processes coordinate themselves and, in some cases, how do they achieve actually their conversion function? The research strategy for the two systems is anchored in the PI's four decades of work, including work on the photosynthetic apparatus of purple bacteria. In case of the first system, the supramolecular organization of the thylakoid membrane will be determined along with its energy transfer and conversion processes. In case of the second system, the ability of the respiratory complexes of mitochondria to harness energy will be determined on the basis of published structures. For both systems a detailed computational description of energy storage and transduction will be provided that extends understanding of these systems beyond what is provided by experiment alone. The findings are expected to resolve apparent discrepancies between structural and functional characteristics of the systems. The research links atomic level supramolecular structure to energy and charge transfer processes through dissipative quantum mechanics and molecular dynamics descriptions.

This project is jointly funded by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and the Physics of Living Systems Program in the Division of Physics.

Intellectual Merit: This project focuses on the mechanisms of energy transfer in photosynthetic membranes of bacteria and plants as well as the respiratory chain supercomplex of mitochondria by employing, extending, and developing new methods in computational bioenergetics and the integration of experimental data of these supramolecular domains. Bioenergetic systems in photosynthesis and respiration utilize similar proteins and physical processes to convert energy efficiently across organelle­ scale distances. Structural modeling, quantum dynamics, molecular dynamics, Brownian dynamics calculations, as well as structure-­based rate kinetics models are combined to investigate molecular mechanisms of energy storage and transduction in photosynthesis and respiration and the rate limiting diffusive behavior of charge carriers involved in energy transfer events. The major aims of the project address the supramolecular organization of bacterial and plant photosynthetic membranes and the corresponding energy conversion processes occurring at and across them.

 14 peer-reviewed articles have been published on five bioenergetic processes in photosynthetic systems and on the development of the computational methods needed to analyze them. The bioenergetic processes, typically carried out through large assemblies of membrane proteins, energy transfer events, and diffusing charge carriers, span broad ranges of length and time scales. First, cell scale visualization of energy conversion in purple phototropic bacteria brings together results obtained on many scales.  Second, the quantum mechanical (QM) and molecular dynamics (MD) analyses of the proton-coupled electron transfer reactions in the cytochrome bc1 complex. Third, the allosteric pathway connecting the flavin and the quinone in respiratory complex I for oxidative phosphorylation. Fourth, light dependence of rate limiting energy conversion steps in the photosystem I-rich (PSI)domain of the thylakoid membrane from the cyanobacterium Prochlorococcus, the most abundant organism on the planet.   For a minimal unit of 4 PSI domains with charge carriers distributed on opposite sides of the membrane, multiple coarse-grained simulations for a total of 20 microseconds produced sufficient trajectories to study the rate limiting diffusive behavior and binding of  the carriers to PSI under different light conditions. Fifth, the charge carrier kinetics of the photosystem II in plants are still ongoing. Computational tools such as interaction network analysis, QM/MM interface to our molecular dynamics program NAMD, constant pH MD simulations, and new visualization methods were developed to analyze the energy transfer events. The new visualization tools implemented into our VMD program enabled the key results to be summarized in the publications and movies  such as the role of bacterial photosynthesis in the “Birth of Planet Earth” film which was shown worldwide.  

Broader Impact: During the funding period three graduate students and three postdoctoral researchers were trained in modeling and simulations of photosynthetic supramolecular domains in bacteria and plants, learning how to break them into smaller manageable systems that were still challenging to simulate using the state-of-the-art NSF and DOE supercomputers. The co-workers were also active in outreach and educational activities aimed for the general public,  especially with the demonstration of the cell-scale organization of 985 light harvesting organelles (chromatophores) in  Rhodobacter sphaeroides cells, containing approximately 2.5 million chlorophylls. The images showcase, on the one hand, new rendering modalities added to VMD for crowded cellular environments developed specifically for cell-scale bioenergetic models, and, on the other hand, a structural model for a low-light-grown Rhodobacter sphaeroides cell with a chromatophore distribution consistent with cryo-ET and AFM experimental data. The structure and function of energy harvesting domains in Rba. sphaeroides at atomic, supra-molecular, organelle, and cellular levels were featured in a cinematic movie, “Birth of Planet Earth”.  

 

Incorporating data from multiscale simulation and modeling on HPC platforms, domain-specific science tools, tools for pre-visualization, camera choreography, artistic modeling tools, rendering on HPC platforms, and tools and techniques used in post production were reported in the high impact journal, Parallel Computing  and on the group webpage – making the information available to a broad scientific audience as well. The movie/documentary “Birth of Planet Earth” has been shown all over the world and is available through Amazon prime.  The movie “Photosynthesis in Chromatophores” featuring the contributions from this funded research at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign  can be seen in youtube  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NTgAok6n7I4.  How fundamental behaviors of metabolism, genetic information processing and photosynthesis within cells emerge from simulations of a minimal photosynthetic bacterial remains an exciting project for the future.
